p: AYA face a number of biological and social barriers to adherence to oral ART, including cognitive development (poor impulse control and lack of future planning) [11] and susceptibility to HIV-related stigma [12]. Adolescents may skip clinic visits to avoid missing school and possibly disclosing their HIV status to teachers and peers [13]. Further barriers to adherence include poor engagement in care, inadequate support transitioning from pediatric to adult care, and not being informed of their HIV status by caregivers [14]. Strategies to increase ART adherence among AYA are needed. Long-acting pharmaceuticals have shown increased adherence compared to daily pills in prior studies of antipsychotics [15] and contraception [16]. Long-acting ART (LA-ART) is a promising potential intervention to overcome the need for daily adherence and improve clinical outcomes in this priority population.
